enigma.console.java2d
Class Java2DTextWindow

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--java.awt.Component
        |
        +--java.awt.Container
              |
              +--javax.swing.JComponent
                    |
                    +--enigma.console.java2d.Java2DTextWindow
All Implemented Interfaces:
ImageObserver, MenuContainer, Scrollable, Serializable, TextWindow
public class Java2DTextWindow
extends JComponent
implements TextWindow, Scrollable

An implementation of TextWindow which uses Java2D to render its display. Java2DTextWindow uses the Monospaced font by default for its output; other fonts may be assigned using setFont(), but only monospaced fonts will function properly.

Java2DTextWindow provides built-in scrollback buffer support. It must be placed in JScrollPane for this support to function.

Author:
Ethan Royael Nicholas (ethan@ethannicholas.com)
See Also:
TextWindow, Serialized Form
Status:
UNSTABLE. Incompatible changes may be introduced in the future, although they are not likely to be drastic.

Constructor Detail

Java2DTextWindow

public Java2DTextWindow(int columns,
                        int rows,
                        int scrollback)
Constructs a new Java2DTextWindow of the specified size. The columns and rows parameters merely control the component's initial and preferred sizes; changes to the component's size will result in these values being recomputed.

The scrollback parameter controls the maximum number of rows that the component will remember at any given time, regardless of the number actually displayed. Therefore, the user will be able to scroll back (scrollback - rows) rows. The rows property, as previously mentioned, may change as the component is resized, but the scrollback property is hidden and immutable.

addTextMouseListener

public void addTextMouseListener(TextMouseListener l)
Description copied from interface: TextWindow
Adds a listener for mouse events. Not all TextWindow implementations will necessarily offer mouse support. TextWindows without mouse support will allow mouse listeners to be added and removed from without error, but will simply never notify the listeners of any events.

It is important to note that the Y coordinate of a TextMouseEvent may be negative when the user has scrolled a TextWindow backwards. Negative Y coordinates indicate lines from the scrollback buffer.

Specified by:
addTextMouseListener in interface TextWindow
Parameters:
l - the listener to add
See Also:
TextWindow.removeTextMouseListener(enigma.event.TextMouseListener)

advance

protected final void advance(char c)

output

public void output(char c)
Description copied from interface: TextWindow

Outputs the specified character at the current cursor position, using the default attributes. The cursor automatically advances to the next position, which may cause the cursor to wrap to the next line or the TextWindow to scroll.

If the character is a newline ('\n'), the cursor is automatically advanced to the next line. A tab ('\t') is expanded to four spaces. No other control characters are supported (for instance, a backspace character does not cause the cursor to move backwards), and unsupported control characters or other unprintable characters will generally render as an error glyph. All TextWindow implementations must support the entire ASCII character set, but support for other character ranges is dependent upon the particular TextWindow implementation.

This method always functions as if in overstrike mode, meaning that the character under the cursor is changed and all other characters are unaffected.

Specified by:
output in interface TextWindow
Parameters:
c - the character to output, which should be a printable character, a tab, or a newline

output

                   TextAttributes attributes)
Description copied from interface: TextWindow

outputImmediately

public void outputImmediately(char c,
                              TextAttributes attributes)
Description copied from interface: TextWindow
Similar to output, but requests that the TextWindow paint the character without delay. This method should only be used to display characters as the user types them, so that they appear on the screen faster; the disadvantage of this method is that overall throughput is greatly reduced, so it should never be used to output more than one character per keystroke.

The request to output the character immediately is merely a hint, and TextWindow implementations are free to treat outputImmediately no differently from output.

Specified by:
outputImmediately in interface TextWindow
Parameters:
c - the character to output
attributes - the TextAttributes with which to render the character

pageUp

public void pageUp()
Description copied from interface: TextWindow
Scrolls the window up one page, if scrolling is supported and the window is not already at the top of its scroll range. Otherwise, this call is ignored.

Specified by:
